transcript.content: Red Hot Chili Peppers - Fortune Faded
Fortune Faded by Red Hot Chili Peppers on Xfm 104.9. With Ricky Gervais, Stephen Merchant, and Karl Pilkington for the last time.
Yes, we've said that before of course, so don't get your hopes up.
(laughing) Yeah, we've had some highs, some lows, some laughs, some tears. Karl, you concentrating?
Lot of tears, mainly from the audience's.
Yeah now before we get into that, before we get into talking about maybe some of the...
Hijinks we've had looking back, looking forward as well.
Yeah.
I came in, Karl was sitting at the desk and he went, "alright?" I went, "alright".
He went, "see that Helen Clarke diaries?" I went, "no, I didn't".
He went, "nor have I. A lot of people talking about it."
He went, "I've never kept a diary. Keeping a diary will always get you into trouble", and I said like Anne Frank. What did you say Karl?
The woman in the cupboard?
That's what he said.
The woman in the cupboard.
And I went save it, save it.
Never speak to Karl off air, save it all for when we're on the wireless
He went, "but what did she do? What did she do except be in a cupboard? What did she have to write about?"
And I said, well, her thoughts.
Do you know Anne Frank?
All I know about Anne is, there's no point pretending-
Anne!
-that I know stuff.
Yeah.
Right, erm...
Tell us everything you know about Anne Frank.
Er, she was in a cupboard
(laughing) Yeah, what else?
If she didn't do that I wouldn't know about her, seriously. That's all I know about her.
Yeah.
So what did she do?
Yeah but what do you think- we know about, we know about 'her cupboard' because of her book, don't we?
But hang on, what, in the bigger scheme of things why was she in a cupboard?
I don't know.
Right.
I honestly don't know.
You don't know anything else about Anne Frank beyond the fact that, to quote you, "she was in a cupboard".
Well what's she done then? You tell me why should I know more about her?
Firstly, I don't think she was in a cupboard.
She wasn't in a cupboard, she was in an attic.
Alright. Well what was she doing?
She was hiding from the-
Tidying up.
She was hiding from the Nazis.
But, isn't that the first place they'd look? Sort of-
Ricky bursts
Work from the top down.
Karl, they weren't specifically looking for Anne Frank.
They weren't going, "Where is she?"
"Where's Frankers?"
"If she gets that book out we are in deep shit! We've got to stop the book!"
They were just looking generally.
She was, I think she was thirteen, fourteen? She was-
Yes.
-hiding. She was Jewish and she was hiding... lived in Amsterdam didn't she?
As much of her family were having to hide.
Yeah.
Being helped by, you know, friends, non-Jewish friends-
In a cupboard and I mean, a cupboard covers you know...
And how long, you know how long did she sort of hide up there for?
Until she was caught.
Long enough to write a book.
So she even got caught after all that?
What do you mean, "so she even got caught"? We're talking about one of the great, you know, humanist tragedies of our times, and you're going,
"She couldn't even stay hidden".
What do you mean, didn't she get caught?
No, I'm just saying like, you know, it's not a great tip then is it. Do you know what I mean, she didn't do it well. She didn't hide and say, "well I escaped it", she got caught.
Her diaries are not a manual on how to hide from people! It's not how to win at hide and seek.

I don't know anything about her, and we might be going down some ground that's a bit dodgy. I don't know enough about it, maybe it's best just leaving it. All I was saying is diaries, you know, what you do them for. Have you kept one Steve?
Never kept a diary, no. I can understand your fear that it might get discovered.
Someone might read it. Find out all about your inner secrets. Course lu-good thing about you is you tell everyone what you think about them.
Yeah.
Yeah but not-
No one's gonna find a diary and go 'Oh god-
'Can't believe it. Karl doesn't like my haricut'.
Yeah, yeah. 'Karl think-Karl thinks I look like Dave Hill from Slade'.
(laughs)
'Yeah I told you that didn't I? Yeah. I told you that'.
Do you think they'll last though? Diaries and that?
Ha!
(suppresses laughter)
What?
No cos they were a bit of a time killer weren't they? It was something to do at the end of the day whereas now there's iPods and that.
(laughs) He's fantastic!
Do you know what I mean?
The iPod of Anne Frank!
Yeah.
No but that's what I mean.
'New from Sony'.
Yeah.
That would be great, wouldn't it? 'All her greatest hits. Who could forget?' Oh, dear.
We'll leave that then.
Should we leave that?
I didn't know it was that deep. I thought it was just like a, y'know-
You thought it was li-didn't you-didn't you-
Adrian Mole type thing.
(laughs)
Now what are we doing?
Play a record.
Thorns from my favourite album of last year, that. And uh, I Can't Remember. We'll be doing a bit of that, playing some of our favourite songs. We've uh got a couple of requests in fact.
Oh really?
Yeah we've got a co-one of them celebrity requests. Matt Lucas from uh Little Britain, he's listening in.
Oh yeah.

Eh 'Is it your last show?', I said yeah. I said 'Do you want me to play a record?'. He said yeah, I said 'What's your favourite group?' Guess Matt Lucas' favourite group. Now remember, him and David are the
New darlings of comedy.
Yeah.
They're cool, they're trendy, everyone loves Little Britain. They're comedy geniuses. They're only gonna get bigger. What's his favourite group of all time?
Um, oh that is tricky. Uh, Level 42?
Um, no. Karl, have a guess.
Well it's gonna be something weird innit if you're saying this.
Well...
So... uh how old? How old's the band?
Eh, they're probably about as old as him.
How old's he?
Oh Karl, have a guess.
ABBA.
No it's uh... why'd you say ABBA?
...they're good aren't they?
Um (laughs) no it's The Proclaimers.
The Proclaimers?!
(laughing) Yeah.
Really?
Yeah. And I know he's listening. But, y'know...
I mean there's nothing wrong with The Proclaimers. I just can't imagine anyone getting that excited about them.
I bet that's why he likes you. Cos you hang out with him don't you?
I do hang out with him.
He thinks he-
I suppose I'm like-yeah.
It's like the closest thing he-he knows one of The Proclaimers.
Wait till he meets my twin brother.
(laughs) He's gonna have a field day isn't he?
He won't believe it.
Yeah. So I was honest, I said 'I can't play The Proclaimers. But we'll play them another-
Where did they
Wh-what-where did they come from? Cos I don't really remember The Proclaimers particularly from when I was younger.
Well let me give you a little blast...(yodels)...but in two part harmony.
Of course.
That was the main thing.
But they were very popular for a while, weren't they?
I think they em had sort of three big hits in-
Yeah.
-sort of about nineteen eighty...sev-when was it?
Yeah. Oh I forget.
Yeah. '80s.
Scottish-they did sing in Scottish accents which I thought was quite refreshing.
Yeah.
They didn't do the fake American thing.
No that was-that was good.
But again I can't imagine sort of being in that... when would I be in the mood to put on a Proclaimers record?
When you run out of Krankies stuff I suppose.
I guess so yeah.
You've played all your Krankies records.
Yeah and your Muppets album.
Yeah, pop on The Proclaimers.
Now we were talking before the break about Anne Frank in her cupboard.
Yes. Yes. I'm still a little bit concerned that Karl's not quite got his head around Anne Frank's diary. It's not like it's a children's book. It's not like "The Lion, Anne Frank and the Wardrobe".
No, no.
She doesn't go into a fantasy land when she goes into the attic.
I'm just glad that Old Mother Hubbard didn't help the Nazis because that's the first place she'd look.
Yeah.
Isn't it? The Nazis would go "we've Old Mother Hubbard, she thinks she knows where she is."
Yeah.
She'd have gone straight there.
I think with Hubbard is I... if I just briefly mentioned Hubbard...
Ricky laughs
Now Hubbard goes to the cupboard to get, I can't remember exactly-
A poor dog a bone-
She goes to get a dog-
-a bone. But when she got there-
-the cupboard was bare
The cupboard was bare, and so the poor dog had none.
Is there more to that than I... Because that's all I remember. Is there further verses? Does she finally get a bone, does she go on an adventure?
What, you mean the second verse is, "then she looked in the fridge and realised that's where she kept the bone and so the dog was laughing."
Exactly.
No, there is another verse.
That's all of it.

I think so. Old Mother Hubbard went to the cupboard to get the poor dog a bone, when she got there the cupboard was bare, and so the poor dog had none. No I think that's the end of it. I think it's the moral that-
What, what's the moral?
Well, if you've got a dog keep some bones in the cupboard.
Right, because I always, even as a kid, I remember thinking
It's quite a tragic sort of picture they paint. I imagine maybe she's lost-
It's short isn't it.
It is pretty short, it's pithy.
It's- that's amazing.
I always wondered whether perhaps she's had a nervous breakdown, maybe her husband's died recently. She's just not got any food.
She doesn't know-

She doesn't know what's going on. The dog's, you know, yapping away. Eventually she kind of wakes out of this kind of depressed stupor, she goes to the cupboard, there's nothing there. It's just a really depressing morbid sort of tale.
I don't know if maybe it's originated from something in history. I know that Jack and Jill who went up the hill and fell down again-
A story about illicit lovers.
That's apparently based on that.
And obviously ring-a-ring-a-rosies, dates-
Plague?
Dates back to plague times, so I dunno about Hubbard.
Erm, Humpty Dumpty? Not so... sure about this. I... this is something I remember... as a kid thinking... what- at what point was it decided that Humpty Dumpty was a giant egg man?
I don't know!
Because there's nothing in the actual rhyme It's not, "Humpty Dumpty the egg man sat on a wall".
My concern is more if, I mean, his parents were a little bit cruel... because if you are The Dumpties...
...of, say, Surrey.
Yeah.
Don't call your firstborn Humpty.
Yeah.
Because straight away it's going to be embarrassing for him in school isn't it. I don't know...
(recites Humpty Dumpty without using words)
Is that it as well?
That's all of it.
Oh god!
And also, I don't mean to be pedantic because I know it's a children's nursery rhyme-
Is it like an Edward Lear thing?
I don't mean to be pedantic again, but if you've got a giant egg man and he's fallen to bits, you know.
All the king's men, fine, they can piece that together again. Don't send horses in.
No.
That's just a...
Whole eggy, horsey mess.
They're gonna make it worse.
They're just gonna be stamping on him.
They are gonna make him worse.
It's not a great idea.
"They're standing on him, get the horse out of the way, now he's definitely d..."
But again, maybe I'm sure some of the you know...

It was probably- if it was... is it pre-Lewis Carroll or...? If it's Lewis Carroll it just came with illustration. There's some- he gave it to someone to illustrate, to illustrate Humpty Dumpty and he goes, "well you've made him an egg!"
"Yeah, a sort of egg with eyes and a face."
Yeah!
I mean I suppose... cause the moral of that is if you're fragile-
If you're an egg-
If you're an enormous egg-
"Mr Dumpty! Get down from the wall." "I'll be fine."
Because I'll tell you what, there'll be no medical-
Accident waiting to happen.
Yeah. I don't know. Karl, what was your favorite nursery rhyme when you were growing up?
Er, I didn't really do that much reading as a kid.
You're joking.
You surprise me.
You're joking.
Erm... what's the one with loads of people in a bed? What's that one?
Oh, there was one in the bed and the little one said roll over. Yeah.
Now cause that's not really even got a story to it is it, it's just-
Hold on though, I'll stop you there, it doesn't even say people. It says 'there was ten in the bed and the little one'. Little what?
They could be anything. I don't know what they are. Roll over- they all rolled over and one fell out. There was nine in the bed and the little one said roll over.
Now where is the little one in the bed?
I don't know, but worse than that... what has he got over the other nine?
That he can demand they roll out the bed.
And why is there one getting back in?
Yeah, they're just lying on the floor.
"We're here now". I don't know.
How does that end as well. Where's that going?
There was one in the bed and the little one said, again he just says- presumably he's just telling himself to roll over.
Yeah.
There was one in the bed and the little one said roll over.
So he rolled over and one fell out - that's him.
That's him.
There was none in the bed and the little one said roll over. So now he's calling the shots presumably laying on a pile of-
Yeah, they're just still rolling around.

I don't know, I don't know Karl. We gotta look into this. If anyone knows why Dumpty was an egg, if Hubbard eventually found a dog a bone, and what was the little one doing? What did the little one think he was doing for God's sake.
When I saw me dad last year. He was telling me about one-
About a fella who's got some clothes you can see through.
What's that one?
You don't mean The Emperor's New Clothes?
Yeah what's that one about?
That's a genuinely good little parable.

Yeah, because it's now used for people who are scared to sort of slag something off because it's sort of like really cool and that, and they don't want to be the one that shouts it. And then one person goes hold on.
Very very briefly, Karl, very very briefly. The king wants some new clothes right? He's a king, he goes, "who's gonna make me some new clothes".
Various people come to him, he says "I don't like that. I don't like that. It's not interesting enough".
One guy who's just a bit of a con artist comes along.
He goes, "I've made you this magic suit, look, and it's nothing." He goes, "put it on".
It's invisible
The king puts on nothing because there is nothing but thinks there's something because you know, he wants to buy into it and everything-
And he goes, "it's the finest stitching, look at it. Can you see it?" They actually say, "only a genius can see how good this suit is".
And the King goes, "yeah, yeah, it's brilliant, it's brilliant. Yeah, it's great." And he goes out and just is it a woman or a little kid-
Well everyone's applauding, they're going, "you look great". Even though his tackle's hanging out, he's you know, he's nothing.
Even though he's got a king size sort of like bit of 'meat and two veg' wobbling- dragging down the street.
Exactly and then one little boy goes, "you're not wearing anything"!
"The king is in the altogether the altogether"... Know that one?
So..did anyone else buy one, or was..?
Ohhh.
Okay play a record Karl
Play a record, Karl, just play a song.
Jesus.
Travis - "writing to reach you" on Xfm 104.9 alright?
Couple of emails here trying to respond to our requests for um nursery rhyme related information.
Oh go on..

Nicky Williams says that she was at infant school and she had a nursery rhyme book and the book ,in the book and this may again, may just be the illustrations but apparently the ten in the bed in there were small baby monkeys, which you'll be loving Karl. But again, I'd I suspect that might just be the illustrator, I never had the book.

I remember I had a book of nursery rhymes when I was little and uh my brother um who was older than me, I was about 5 so he was about 16. I remember him and his mate just absolutely cracking up becase it said um up Jack drot and um..up Jack got and home did trot as fast as he could caper he went to bed and bandaged his nob N O B with vinegar and brown paper. I've since found out the nob is like the old English for head, but I didn't know why they were laughing
Course
They were just cracking up this this was..
Whenever one my mate's brothers came round, he came up and said 'where's your nursery rhyme book. and he'd read it to 'em.
Yeah
And it was just the funniest thing in the world.
The brown paper and vinegar was a popular method because didn't Jack and Jill use that, they used something similar?
That was Jack and Jill.  Yeah, that's Jack when he broke his crown which obviously oh that means his head as well. Doesn't it?
Yeah,
Yeah yeah yeah
So he's fractured his skull on a sort of like an outcrop of rock.
Yeah,
And then uh
Is that still used the brown paper vinegar?
I don't think it is.
I don't know maybe in Manchester they're still using that I'm not sure
Yeah
Tracey and John Burton say that they reckon Humpty Dumpty was actually a cannon that used to sit on the walls of the castle in Colchester where they live
Th-that makes sense.
Yeah, that would make a lot more sense
..up on the wall, had a great fall
All the kings men couldn't put 'im together again so he had to go "Oh, I broke the cannon
Or it meant it exploded
Maybe the cannon fell apart
Because people used to get blown up by cannons. Just doing it wrong didn't they?
Sure
Which is where "hoist by your own petard"
Right
Where that comes from right,
Right right right
Coming back and blowin' up in your face.
That makes slightly more sense. Because he would want to send for the King's Men then.
Yeah, and the horses
I think the horses just came along anyway cus it was interesting
Well they, well no, that was quicker
Sure

They were the quick King's Men. It took 'em about three minutes but the horses were there in about a minute. so uh, but I mean if it blew up there was nothing they could do. So uh, so we've got to the bottom of that
See look, educational Karl see this is real education.
Mm... It's just got a bit heavy tho innit?
What at what Humpty Dumpty. Yeah, it has got a little bit heavy. Let's try and let's dumb it down a little bit what you want to do Mary Mary Quite Contrary?
We doin Rockbusters in a bit?
Hang on a minute
What?
Before you even get to Rockbusters. Ooh man alive.
There are loads more verses to Old Mother Hubbard
Are there?!
I'm gonna digest these while we play the ads and I'll see if there's any salient information I can give you after.
Brilliant!
Delays.
Long time coming on XFM 104.9, with Ricky Gervais, Steven Merchant and Karl Pilkington for the last time.
Sad.
Umm, we've established that Hubbard went to the cupboard Rick.
Yeah.
Get the dog bone, the cupboard was empty, as we all know. And the dog went...
Yeah. So the dog didn't have any, end of story. So the dog didn't have any.
Well no, no, no, no, wait.
Hold on. Go on. What, what, what, what.
It turns out there's ahh, what appears to be something like 15 other verses.
Not really?
Unbelievable. I'm not gonna go through all of them Rick.
Right. Any, any, any, um, any information, go on.
Well basically I can tell you straight away, the dog, the dog initially had none.
Yeah.
She went to the baker's to buy him some bread, when she came back the poor dog was dead. Right? You're pretty upset about that.
Yeah.
She went to the joiners to buy him a coffin, when she came back the poor dog was laughing. I don't know what he's up to.
Right, ahh.
She took a clean dish to get him some tripe and but when he came back, when she came back, he was smoking a pipe. I mean.
Hold on, so the dog was winding her up then at the beginning being dead?
The dog's just. I mean he's pushing his luck. Especially if she's already depressed.
But, but d'you know what if I was that dog. Right.
And I lived with old Mother Hubbard, right. All that faffing around, I'd be going "I know there's no bones in the cupboard."
Exactly.
Right. "What do you mean, you're gonna get me some bread? I'm a dog, I'm not interested in bread. Get, get get me some hamburgers."
Yeah
So I'd start, I think I'd start winding her up.
She went to the alehouse to get him some beer, when she came back the dog sat in a chair.
See I'd've said, "the dog had turned queer."
Yeah. It doesn't scan very well does it.
Make it rhyme at least, and also get a little, you know. He's ahh, he's smoking a pipe. He's having a laugh.
I'm beginning to wonder if.
He's bent. He's bent.
I'm, I'm beginning to wonder if this is based on fact though, in any way, because she went to the grocers to buy him some fruit, when she came back he was playing the flute.
He's gay.
No, it is the flute. It's not ahh(mumbles)
Now this. I didn't even know there was a goat involved.
Oh noo.
She went to the tailor's to buy him a coat, when she came back he was riding the goat.
Eyah. There you go. Dirty little ohh what
She went to the hat, well, she went to the hatters to buy him a hat, when she came back he was feeding the cat. I mean...
I can't believe it. So I'm thinking the pipes a crack pipe.
Hang on a minute. Hang on a minute. You're get, I think the gay things beginning to stand up.
Go on. Ooh.
She went to the barbers to buy him a wig, when she came back...
He was having a frigg?
(Laughs) He was dancing a jig.
(Laughs)
He was dancing a jig. You're dancing a jig.
Ohh, he's dancing a jig, smoking a pipe, shagging a goat.
This is a, this is a bit of left field one though, she went to the Cobblers to buy him some shoes.
(Laughs) Why does he need shoes? I bet they're, I bet they're high heels.
Wait a second though. She went to the cobblers to buy him some shoes, when she came back, you're never gonna believe this, he was reading the news. He was reading the news.
(laughs) Brilliant!
Umm, she went to the seamstress to buy him some linen. Again, I don't know why, when she came back the dog was a spinning.
Yep.
She went to the hoosiers to buy him some hose, when she came back he was dressed in his clothes.
Aha yeah, but why did she want to get him?
This is, this is the big payoff that we've been building to.
Alright
The Dame
-made a curtsy, the dog made a bow. The Dame said, "your servant", the dog said, "bow-wow".
Right.
I mean
Okay.
I... you know.
I'm going to probably do a few more verses during the next song.
During the course of the show?
Yeah.
Listen, before we move on, I should just say that we've had various people saying what was in the bed and what was the final line of the bed-
Yeah.
-thing.
Why do they care?
It's extraordinary, isn't it? We've talked about politics in the past, great music, we've played great songs.
Yeah. We've got monkey news coming up (talking about politics).
But Danny's said that apparently it ends with one in the bed little one said good night.
Because he was all happy, he had the bed to himself.
But Eva-
There's nine of his mates piled on the floor-
Rick, but Eva counters that by saying actually one in the bed little one said come back. Because he felt lonely.
So...
We're never gonna get to the bottom of this.
I don't know, Rick.
This is the same as the Kennedy thing, there's loads of different opinions.
(over Ricky) Conspiracy theories.
I know, we don't know what's going on.
Bit of Jimmy Webb would be good.
Jimmy Webb - Galveston
Jimmy Webb - Galveston. Fantastic version. On Xfm 104.9.
You know what Steve I know people going to miss the talk about little Chinese fellas, little gay fellas, little monkey fellas and all that, but I think they're going to miss some great tunes as well.
I'd hope so.
She went to the jeweller's to buy him a clock, but when she got back...
What was he sucking?
A choc ice.
A choc ice, fine.
So...
Fine, respectable.
Yeah.
Erm, yeah, I sort of feel like, you know, one thing we've never done, Rick, is we've never pandered to people but as it's the last show, erm, we've got to give the audience what they want-
Rockbusters?
Well, yeah, and I was gonna say things they don't want as well.
Ricky laughs
You know, and well just basically to keep a smile on Karl's face.
Yeah.
I say a smile - a sort of not quite a scowl.
Yeah, he never really smiles.
So, erm, yeah, it's just- really it's a chance for him to have a go. It's like, you know, you indulge a- an annoying child.
The only time Karl laughs is for no apparent reason.
Yeah.
What do you think-
What do you mean?
Well, sometimes you'll go, "heh". And I know you'll be thinking of what a monkey could do.
Yeah, it's like it's like people who have had electroshock therapy.
(laughing) Yeah! I just imagine him tied down biting on something.
Exactly, yeah.
Biting on a big leather pad.
Let me just tell you briefly what the prizes are-
That- that looks like a piece of shit you've got there.
Let me tell you, Rick. There's a number of mediocre CDs and DVDs-
That is real tat.
-but mainly what about this, it's The Lord of the Rings Collector's Edition-
Ooooh!
What, the movies you thinking?
No, it's the Radio 4 adaptation. It's only 14 hours long, Rick.
Ohh that is... throw that away! Pop that in the bin!
That is just... Either pop it in the bin or send it to some poor bastard who wins this quiz.
Exactly. If you're willing to take part in the quiz, you deserve 14 hours of your life wasted with that Tolkien tripe.
Ricky laughs
Right.
So what are the clues again Karl?
Right. As always, just you know cryptic clues and that, initials of a band or an artist. Work it out, win the stuff.
Um..
Email only.
Yeah. ricky.gervais@xfm.co.uk. First clue is as follows...ehm..
(laughs)
The Jamaican fella wrote a review for -
OH HO HO!
It's the good old Jamaican fella!
He's back!
The Jamaican fella!
OH, it's the last show and the little Jamaican fella has made an appearance.
This normally suggests that you need to think of the answer in a Jamaican accent.
Yeah. Or not.
Yeah or not.
Yeah. Any accent. Or an accent. Or pronounce the word slightly differently.
Yeah okay.
Yeah, go on.
The Jamaican fella wrote a review for Phoenix Nights.
Alright?
Yeah.
D.C. are the initials.
D.C.?
Yeah.
D for Derek?
Yeah.
Okay.

Yeah, D.C. The Jamaican fella wrote a review for Phoenix Nights, that's the first one. Um, second one. There's three of 'em. Second one is uh we should all vote for Paul Daniels, David Blaine, Copperfield, The Great Suprendo, Tommy Cooper and Derren Brown. We should all vote for them. Why's that? What was...
(laughs)
What's the initial?
I just got the first one.
E.S.
E.S.?
E.S.
Okay.
And the last one. Ehm...
Steve, what did your dad do?
Steve what did my dad do?
What did your dad do?
Is that the question or are you asking me?
Well, Ricky what did your dad do? It can work on anyone.
Right.
What did your dad do?
Alright.
Alright, that's E. Alright?
What's your dad do...
So quickly, again - The Jamaican fella wrote review for Phoenix Nights, alright - D.C. Second one. We should all vote for Paul Daniels, David Blaine.
Yeah, yeah yeah go on.
No but that's important. Right.
Ricky laughs
E.S., and the last one, you know, Steve. What did your dad do? Alright, initial E.
Ricky.Gervais@xfm.co.uk - we don't want to speak to you. Please don't phone up.
Remember you could win some Lord of the Rings tripe.
Alright.
"Alright, alright"
Last Rockbusters ever thank god...
Faith No More - I'm Easy
Faith No more and their version of I'm Easy on Xfm 104.9. Ricky Gervais, Steve Merchant, Karl Pilkington - Rick...
For the last time.
We - we've only really got three topics of discussion, on the show. I think you'd agree with that.
Errrrm, little Chinese fellows?
Little Chinese fella's
Monkeys?
Monkeys.

Oh, forget that.
Yeah. What's the number, Steve?
Oh, I don't know.
Oh forget that, we haven't got time.
Yeah, ye- he-he hates answering it, we'll put, we'll do it during the record.
Leave it. Leave it, leave it.
Phone in if you want to speak to Karl, if you know the number, call in, try and convince Karl to kiss little nipple.
Don't want to.
Yeah.
Right, what we doing, are we uhh.
What's the last Educating Ricky, come on.
Uhhhm...
Pause.
Hook, line and good thinkers?
Brilliant, okay.
Yeah, sound's good, go on what is it?
Umm,
Ricky sighs
They've uh, they've found a lot of fish with two heads.
Ricky laughs.
What d'you think of that?
Well,
Steve laughs.
Dunno. Wha- what d'you mean they've found a lot of fish with two heads, who has?
They've been messing about, basically, these scientists...
No.
...and stuff, and they've said: "Look at this we can do"
N-
And they're making loads of fish, with two heads.
-They're actually, they can do it now and they're saying "That's good, innit?". Do you know what I mean?
Ricky sighs
Alright, play a record then.
Yeah, but what do you think?
I think if they can do that to fish, they should try and do it to you and then it at least you'd have two brains to work with.
Yeah
And we won't-
Arguing- I'd love you arguing with yourself. And you end up just, you're walking down the street where you're just headbutting each other. Just cracking- cracking heads in the middle.
Imagine the squeezing-fun you'd have, Rick.
I wouldn't know what to do, I'd bang them together. It would be like one of those Ker-Knackers you used to have in the playground, on the string.
Steve laughs
Yeah
I'd just whack them together. I hit you over on the window, didn't I? To see what the noise meant, today, didn't I?
(mumbling) Yeah
What-
Just- if I had two heads, right?..
Ricky and Steve start giggling
Would I be able to sort of, do shifts? Do you know what I mean? Say- say if- say if this is the start of something, they're trying it out with fish and that, with two heads...
You'd be two different people. You- you can't think like you're one. It doesn't make sense that- (muttering) if you have two heads, you'd have two brains. You'd have, you know.
Yeah. Well, that's all right but say if we did the same job. Well, we'd- we'd be doing the same job.
Yeah, you could.
So you could say "Right, you work through the night..."
But you'd- but you'd both, you'd take it in turns to do your job badly and moan about it. Yes, it'd me fine.
Pause
He's giving it some serious thought.
I know, yeah and so is his other head.
Steve chuckles
Yeah
But also, they're saying there's like a fish shortage-
Right.
-And I was wondering whether they do in like- they try and make that better, do you know what I mean? So they'd do like a-
Yeah, it would. As (stutters) the head is the bit you through away, it'd be perfect.
Steve laughs
No, but when they do a head count, like they do. That's what they do, they do like a-
They- they- what they count fish. They get a fish and go "Okay, just in a line. One. Two." I think you'll find we're one, Sir. "Don't answer back!"
Steve inhales a breath
Rick, uhm. I should just point out that I feel-
"Don't answer back!"
C'mon, I think Karl has offered nothing now. I think those Educating Ricky's were appalling.
They were rubbish!
And the only thing, Rick. The only thing that would redeem the show is if he kissed your nipples.
(high pitched mumbling) Kiss the nipples! Phone in if you want to speak to Karl. You know the number. Call in and try persuade Karl while this record is on.
(talking over each other) It's not. It's not happening.
Well, answer the phone. Answer the phone.
(muttering) No, no.
Kings of Leon - California Waiting

Phones are still going mad. Answer one, just put someone there- Kings of Leon. California Waiting. He was rude- he's so rude to people. They phone up and they say "Aw, kiss his nipple" and he;s going "Yeah, alright" and he hangs up on them. Answer the phone!
What am I meant to say to someone?
Put them on air. Answer the phone and be nice to whoever it is. Be nice to them at least!
We shouldn't- we shouldn't- we shouldn't be putting people on the air.
(to caller) Hello?
Karl.
Yeah, speak to Karl.
Alright?
Why- why don't you speak about that human monkey that was on the other day?
Oh, old news man. How long have you been listening?
Ricky snorts with laughter
Can we forget the monkeys? What do you think of his nipples?
Alright then, just kiss- kiss his nipple then for 500 quid.
I'm not going to kiss his nipple.
I'd do it for 500 quid, easy.
Would you?
Yeah
But why- what- what- why do you want me to do it anyway. What are you getting out of that?
Oh, c'mon mate. 500 quid, it's worth it.
Yeah but (moans)
He's got the money. You could probably get more out of him, if you want.
Ricky laughs
It's not about the money, really.
Think- think of Suzanne. Suzanne, you come home. 500 quid and you go "There you go. Just, I kissed his nipple. 250 quid each."
She gives me more.
Ricky snorts
That's mad.
(muttering) It's not happening, alright? It's not happening.
Steve laughs
Did you just- did you just cut him off then?
Well, there's another fella there.
Who's that? Who's that?
Hello, my name's Linda.
Right. Alright, Linda. You alright?
Yeah
What would make your day, Linda?
Uhm, if Karl actually gave it a lick. Not just a kiss.
Ricky explodes with laughter
Forget it.
The Cure on Xfm 104.9, Pictures of You and it's Ricky Gervais, Stephen Merchant, Karl Pilkington hosting the final show. Exciting.
Which means the last film quiz. Karl puts himself in a film.
Claire's on next week, by the way and then--
Claire Sturgess, then Adam and Joe, brilliant.
Adam and Joe coming back.
Excellent.
They're excellent.
Matt Lucas said he'd do a show. Give him a call and maybe him and Dave Walliams.
Alright, might do that.
What do you think of that?
Might do that.
Yeah, that'd be good, wouldn't it?
Right, yeah. The film thing. This is when we get like, a film and I'm in it. Right? So I'm doing, we talked a bit about you know, a bit about gay fellows and that today.
Yep.
So we're doing When Harry Met Barry. All right? And listen to this and then there'll be a question at the end and you can win some more stuff. We've got DVDs--
Some more shite.
Some more good CDs and DVDs and that.
All right, let's hear it.
So When Harry Met Barry, all right.
Got 18 hours to kill before we get to New York.
I know, yeah. Brought a few books, just to kill a bit of time on the journey.
When I buy a new book, I always read the last page first. That way in case I die before I finish, I know how it ends.
I read a book like that once. Not on purpose though, it was just that all the chapters had been put in the wrong order, so it was a bit annoying. Got to chapter one before I realised.
Are you finished now?

Yeah, I bought another copy of it and read it in Lanzarote, it was all right. Good read. Listen, we're only staying in New York for a couple of days, aren't we? 'Cause the place does my head in a bit.
Oh really?
Yeah, it just stinks, doesn't it? It's a really dirty city. It's noisy.
It's funny, the people who live there call it the city that never sleeps. I'm not surprised with all the noise.
I couldn't agree more.
Listen, I know you're gay and that, right? What, what is the attraction with New York for you lot? What...
'Cause it is like, the gay capital, isn't it? They all love it. Even that Rod Stewart song, you know, that Killing of Georgie, that was set in New York, wasn't it?
Yes, it was!

Yeah, well that song was about a gay fellow, wasn't it? Who moved to New York and ended up getting beaten up. Not a great advert for the place. You keep going there. Actually, I know why you like it, it's because it's the city that never sleeps, isn't it? You lot like going out late, sort of running your life to a different timetable to everyone else.
Are you finished now?
I'm not being funny, I'm just saying. I just don't think you should live your life like that, that's all.
Why not?
Don't start getting angry, I'm just--
Well, I think I'm entitled to throw a little anger your way. Especially when I'm being told how to live my life!
Yeah, yeah, you're right. It is your life and that's what I'm saying, don't be dragging me into it.
What!
Well you know I'm not gay, so why did you buy me a butt plug for my birthday? I'm not gonna use it.
What do you want me to do about it? I take it back, okay? I take it back.
Right.
[Karl in a film]
Wanna spend a night in a motel?
No.
Why not?
Cause you're gay and I'm straight, that's why.
Why aren't you seeing anyone?!
Well y— I'm seeing Suzanne again. We only split up for a few weeks when she had that funny haircut that made her look like Dave Hill out of Slade...
Ricky bursts out laughing
...it's grown again now.
She looked weird, didn't she?
Well, but forget that. Anyway, don't want to share a bed with you again. Not after last time.
Oh, jeez. What are we supposed to do?
This isn't normal, mate. Pull over...
Alright, alright.
...forget it, no pull over.
Don't you—
I don't want to talk about it. Pull over, just pull over.
I was a— come on.
Just pull over here, there's nothing— get a B&B. And by that I mean bed and breakfast...
Ricky laughs
...not bum and bollocks as
You called it, right.
Let's get one thing straight.
I'm not interested! See ya!
Ricky and Steve laugh
Oh, dear.
Excellent.
Oh, little Karl Pilkington.
"When Harry Met Barry", it's a classic film.
What's the—
What song was I talking about that, you know...
Yeah, we know. What song were you t—
...about New York and stuff.
Yeah, what song. Yeah, OK, brilliant.
Artist will do or the song title, whatever.
Yep, OK.
Email only, ricky.gervais@xfm.co.uk. We can squeeze in a tune and then I hope...
Oh, Monkey News!
The final Monkey News.
Ohhh...
What tune have we got? How long is it?
Three minutes, it's a nice one though.
Brilliant, brilliant.
Bit of Aimee Mann?
Fantastic.
Aimee Mann - Red Vines
"Red Vines", Aimee Mann. Well we've been playing some of our favourite tunes and after Monkey News, Justin Lee Collins. We're going to leave you with one of our mutual favorite tracks of all time.
We won't say what it is yet.
We won't sure what it is — it's a little surprise. Then Justin Lee Collins is in with little Boyd Hilton, Karl's twin brother.
The answer to Karl's quiz question — Karl, what was the question?
It was what was the song that I was talking about in that...
"Harry Met Barry".
Yep.
With Billy Crystal. "The Killing of Georgie".
Yep, Rod Stewart.
Steven Farran from Essex wins another...
DVDs and stuff.
Bag of tat.
Alright?
Well, this is the final one, play the jingle.
Ohh, chimpanzee that! Monkey News ya ffffff—
Right. Well, this Monkey News story, right, it's about this fella, couple of fellas in Texas.
Yep.
Sort of running a farm.
Yep.
Right?
Just— they're definitely fellas were they? How tall were they?
Steve chuckles
Yeah, no no no.
Can we just let him tell the story.
They—
OK, they are human beings, these two are human beings?
...time's against us here.
They're running this farm an' that. Anyway, so they're outside getting the cattle and he turns round, right.
Says "that cow's..."

Couple of monkeys walking about. So he goes "what's going on?", right? So anyway, so it's in Texas, they don't know what to do with the monkeys. There isn't a zoo, it's fairly barren there, innit? D'you know what I mean, not much going about.
Yeah.
So the other fella who runs the farm with him
Said "look, we need a bit of a hand"...
[whispering] Oh, f...
Right?
...Jesus Christ.
So, said "let's teach 'em some stuff". And the monkeys were happy with that because they were lost anyway, right, so they had...
They had nothing to do. They were bumming around, they were looking for work.
They'd hired a motor home, they'd gone out of their way.
Yeah. Maybe it's like the Hulk, they were like Bruce Banner wandering around going "I need some work". "You won't get angry will ya?" "No".
So anyway they taught these monkeys how to ride a horse, right? So they've both got...
Steve chuckles
Sorry, you sure Charlton Heston's not gonna pop up?
They both...
You sure you weren't watching a video last night and thought it was a documentary?
Got a horse each right? They've been given like a little lasso and all that-
Oh, don't talk shit Karl.
(inaudible) Right.
So anyway it's going well, it carried on for about two years, this, right?
'Course it did.
It's like, you know, rounding up the cattle every night, and all that.
Yeah, yeah. Yeah, yeah yeah.
So um... the two fellas are chattin', goin', "this works out well, doesn't it, and that."
Right, if there's a hostile takeover and they sort of like buy up 51% of the shares or summat-
So they said, for this to continue, the monkeys are gettin' old a bit now, we need a, we need a little woman monkey in 'ere to sort of get some kids going, for like, future farm people, right?
Forward planning, yeah.
So they get a little woman monkey-
They've decided to only- to hire monkeys from now on.
Why not? Why not? It's working - why mess with something when it's not broke? Right, so they get, they get the little woman monkey in, uh, they have kids and all that business, right?
Mm.
But the problem was, right, when they first got the woman monkey in, it was like well, which one's going to have the woman, right?
Right.
So, they started sort of fightin' a bit and what have you. Yeah, because it's seen the owners of the farm, like, havin' guns and stuff.
Don't lie. Don't tell me the baby monkeys didn't want to go into the family business, one went off to be a lawyer.
They had a bit of a shoot-off.
Shut. Up!
They got two monkeys, right, and-
Don't. Ahhhhh for-- Shhhhh--
Because they'd seen the owners, they'd seen the owners with guns and what have you-
Don't-- no!
Yeah, yeah yeah yeah yeah. No, no no that's how (inaudible)
They had a bit of a shoot-off.
Yeah.
That's how, that's how they sorted it out.
And who won?
I think it was George, the one called George.
Right.
So there- that- I think they had 17 kids, the farm's still running.  So that's- that's like the the last little monkey news now, a good little happy ending to that one.
Rick, would it count if you were to rub your nipple against his lips while I held him down?
Right, come off it now. Come on. No, I'm not doing this.
Bruce Springsteen, "Thunder Road," last track on XFM with Ricky and Steve.
Get off!
You can check it all out on the webcam.
(protesting wordlessly)
I've sort of got (inaudible)
Get his arm out the way, get his arm out the way!
This happened on Scum.
(cackling)

synopsis.description: Werther's a will there's a way
